sentence: The function of criticism describes the rise and fall of British literary criticism.
It constitutes the postscript to Terry Eagleton's previous book "Literary Theory," which describes the major trends in recent literary criticism.
According to "The Function of Criticism," modern criticism began with "The Speaker and the Spectator," expressing a revolutionary new society's understanding of itself.
Since then, there has been no similar consensus on the goals of our society.
Therefore, the status of literary critics declined from Edison to the "literary figure" of the 19th century, and ultimately became scholars of the 20th century.

At some point in the 19th century, there began to be a divergence between critics who increasingly viewed literature as a "treasure trove of common human wisdom" and those who retreated into increasingly narrow fields of expertise.
Censorship is the last important attempt to link well-trained discussions on individual works with broader discussions on the development of society as a whole.
But in the long run, this has not established closer connections between universities and the larger public, or even with their own students.
Recently, the English department has been blocking itself behind a series of powerful literary theories to resist those who challenge their teaching rights.

The last few sections of "Literary Theory" promote Eagleton's own favorite literary method, which links literature with "the way we organize our lives together".
This is the method of Marxism.
However, Eagleton found that Marxist thought did not fully and satisfactorily cover a field of 'we live together'.
He subtly referred to it as the 'intimate realm' or 'intimate area'.
It is here that he recently discovered Freud's usefulness: Freudianism is a science dedicated to liberating humanity from things that hinder its realization and happiness.
In this regard, it shares similarities with radical politics.

Eagleton analyzed how Freud and Marx got along in his five page book "Sons and Lovers": we can discuss Paul's "weak" image of his father and his "strong" image of his mother from the perspectives of Oedipus and class; We can see that the interpersonal relationships between an absent and violent father, an ambitious and emotionally demanding mother, and a sensitive child are understandable, both from the perspective of unconscious processes and certain social forces and relationships.
From Eagleton's discussion of this novel, it appears that Paul does have an Oedipus complex towards his mother, but he prefers his father over what he tells himself.

After this demonstration, Eagleton felt qualified to refute all those amateur "critics who dislike the entire methodology and prefer to work with weak premonitions, intuition, and sudden perceptions".

Criticism and Ideology "(1976)," Marxism and Literary Theory "(1976), and Walter Benjamin's" Towards Revolutionary Criticism "(1981) are Eagleton's early works on the function of criticism.
The most important of these are criticism and ideology.
Eagleton claimed in the book that he laid the theoretical foundation for the British Marxist critical school.
In the new, Eagleton style criticism, the structure of the work is no longer simply seen as a "microcosm or code of ideology" like earlier, more "reductionist" forms of Marxist criticism.
Ideology is not the 'truth' of a text.

Text constitutes a structure: it constructs ideology in order to reconstruct it in a relatively autonomous way, in order to process and reshape it in aesthetic production, while itself is also subject to varying degrees of destruction due to the influence of ideology.

In this destructive practice, the text encounters ideology, which is a relatively structured form that presses upon its own unique values and relationships. It faces a 'concrete logic' that constitutes the periphery of the text's own production.

In the latter half of Critique and Ideology, Eagleton elaborates on his modern Marxist approach through a brief overview of 19th century novels.

Dickens' understanding of the social reality at that time conflicted with his traditional 'bourgeois ethics'; George Eliot avoided the tragic contradictions that existed in her rural society; Conrad's attitude towards British imperialism is fundamentally contradictory.

Pamela "is a comic by Eagleton that tells the story of women as pawns in the interests of the bourgeoisie.
Clarissa is a comic about women as victims of patriarchal oppression.
Clarissa's family and Lovelace are her oppressors.
The language of her society is one of the tools that oppresses her.
She has always been obedient to permissible words, imprinted by her trained power network of obedience.
It was from this network that Lovelace attempted to liberate her so that he could print her through his own more sinister power network - a tangled metaphor.

Warner did indeed expose his emotional issues quite lewdly, but he at least carefully studied some of the language strategies used by Lovelace and Clarissa in close proximity.
Eagleton showed no signs of doing this for himself.
Eagleton believed that Lovelace was Clarissa's main oppressor.
Her family motivation can be explained in Marxist class terms, but what is his motivation?

Afterwards, Eagleton avoided further discussion of Lovelace.
To achieve this, he must talk about Clarissa, whom he has been avoiding.
Then, he must discover what has had such a devastating impact on each person, because apart from Lovelace's pain, we cannot imagine Clarissa's pain.

Looking back at his early article about Jude the Obscure, this can be seen.
In this book, he has not yet assembled the device he currently uses to conceal his limitations as a critic, namely the combination of Marx and Freud.
Eagleton quoted Hardy's own description of the novel, calling it a 'deadly war between the body and the mind'.

Eagleton was eager to explain that this deadly war between "body and spirit" should be interpreted as a "war between the human spirit and the obstructive body of stubborn society" - "Judas" should be seen as a novel about social injustice.
But Hardy refers to more specific things than Jude's war with society, he refers to Jude's disastrous relationship with women, especially Sue.
Eagleton avoided talking about Su's behavior.
On the contrary, in a series of distinctive echoing phrases, he expressed some left-handed praise for Hardy, praising him for recording Su's "emotional structure" in a realistic "opaque" way:.
Her elusive complexity partly stems from the fact that she transcends herself and points to a chaotic and ambiguous emotional structure that belongs to the entire period.

Therefore, her opacity and inconsistency as a character are not just personal traits, nor evidence of Hardy's failure to fully realize them; It is in her opacity and contradictions that she is most fully aware of this and most representative.
But Hardy knew exactly what happened between Su and the man who loved her.
Her contradictions are far from opaque, and every evasive response she makes has its reasons.
Like Clarissa later on, Eagleton never discovered what they were.
